Asian stocks declined, following a U.S. slump overnight, as escalating tension between the U.S. and North Korea dominate sentiment in financial markets this week.Investors made a beeline for safe havens assets amid a surge in volatility gauges, ending their longest stretch of calm in history.The Singapore-traded SGX Nifty, an early indicator of NSE Nifty 50 index’s performance in India, dropped little over 1 percent to 9,762 as of 6:35 a.m.Here’s a quick look at all that could influence equities on Friday.






Global Cues






The S&P 500 Index lost 1.5 percent to 2,438.25 at 4 p.m. in New York. That’s the steepest slide since May 17 and the lowest close since July 11.The Nasdaq Composite Index sank 2.1 percent and the Dow Jones Industrial Average lost 200 points.Friday’s CPI data in the U.S. will get close attention following an unexpected drop in wholesale prices in July.





#BQMarketsNow | U.S. stocks drop most since May over rising Geopolitical concerns.https://t.co/ccDPHDYZs9 pic.twitter.com/RToxxblW6X— BloombergQuint (@BloombergQuint) August 11, 2017






EuropeEuropean markets closed lower as investors reacted to corporate earnings and monitored geopolitical tensions surrounding North Korea.






Asian Cues






Australia’s S&P/ASX 200 Index fell 0.5 percent as of 10:05 a.m. in Sydney. South Korea’s Kospi index lost 1.6 percent.The VIX rose 45 percent to 16.12, it’s highest closing price of Trump’s presidency.Japanese markets are closed for the Mountain Day public holiday.






Commodity Cues






West Texas Intermediate crude added 0.2 percent to $48.67 a barrel in early Friday trading after falling 2 percent Thursday.Gold traded gained 0.2 percent to $1,288.66 an ounce and is up over 2 percent this week.ICE sugar ended lower for eight straight session at $13.24 a pound, down 2.93 percent
